[{'created': '2018-07-12 14:21:36.000000000', 'message': "Use 'become' for destroy container playbook.

Due to the use of delegation to localhost in this task,
we also need to set 'become' otherwise the task does not
have access to the socket because it's executed as the
user running the playbook (zuul).

Change-Id: I999aa55269348497154a8eb073c2ff663242af4e
"}]
commit_message:
Use 'become' for destroy container playbook.

Due to the use of delegation to localhost in this task,
we also need to set 'become' otherwise the task does not
have access to the socket because it's executed as the
user running the playbook (zuul).

Change-Id: I999aa55269348497154a8eb073c2ff663242af4e

commit_message:
Remove unicode from tox.ini

tox -e pep8 would fail as this is run through an ascii decode
by flake

Change-Id: I4d5755ea445d8dc3b505940cb737405d8e0cbc89

commit_message:
Raise ansible forks to 25

This patch raises the value of ansible forks to 25 from the default of
5 so we can deploy faster when deploying more than 5 nodes.

Change-Id: I76b7d76f5eab50ae1908834a0234bca57f3f19c3

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I3868de365369664b3689582cc9d25f3228e5dbb7
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Switch to using stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1] stestr is
maintained project to which all Openstack projects
should migrate.
Let's switch it then.

Also sync the version of the requests-mock to
the current global requirements.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Signed-off-by: Charles Short <zulcss@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Luigi Toscano <ltoscano@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I599c74c3ac152c0fc1bc0dddfda8c05a41ddf5a1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-06-08 16:02:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-08 22:26:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)

Given the discussions we've had on the performance etherpad and nearby, it seems like there are a small number of details to work out with regard to how this will be called and how we will know it should be called.

There also seems to be some discussion on whether we should use /migrator all the time. Presumably if there are performace concerns about getting allocations all the time, then the answer to that is "no".

Some nits and questions within but overall I think this captures the issues pretty well. I'm glad that Eric is approaching it from a fairly general standpoint. I reckon that writing good tests is going to be key to us getting this right.

I'll provide some additional text on PlacemetDirect tomorrow. It's guaranteed to be more cogent then.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-09 12:40:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

I've provided some text, not all that different from what was there."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-09 14:59:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-06-11 12:48:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-06-11 15:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(20 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-06-12 00:51:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-06-12 01:03:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

(7 comments)

Still +2 on this. The public API parts are agreed-to and solve the problem at hand. While we can go back and forth on the virt-driver update_provider_tree() interface/details, that's not a public API and if we need to make some changes after implementing this go-round, so be it.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:30:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:36:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

As in the previous rev, I think we need to be very clear that the migrator path can't happen during the periodic, which is also what Jay is calling out."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:52:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-06-19 09:43:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Honestly, we could discuss more and more about some details, but I think we now have at least a consensus about both the new Placement API resource needed, plus when and where to call it. We know it could be a performance impactful series, but we accept to discuss about it during the implementation, not now (as at least we need to see the WIP changes).

I know we're after the spec deadline, but the nova team accepted to have this spec to be merged as an exception."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-19 11:29:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-05 23:17:53.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Spec: Handling Reshaped Provider Trees

Saving my work.

Change-Id: I1508c8e12c75b24ec9da04468b700b60f055ec24
blueprint: reshape-provider-tree
'}, {'created': '2018-06-06 19:24:09.000000000', 'message': 'Spec: Handling Reshaped Provider Trees

Virt drivers need to be able to change the structure of the provider
trees they expose. When moving existing resources, existing allocations
need to be moved along with the inventories. And this must be done in
such a way as to avoid races where a second entity can create or remove
allocations against the moving inventories.

Change-Id: I1508c8e12c75b24ec9da04468b700b60f055ec24
blueprint: reshape-provider-tree
'}, {'created': '2018-06-06 19:24:43.000000000', 'message': 'Spec: Handling Reshaped Provider Trees

commit_message:
Spec: Handling Reshaped Provider Trees

Virt drivers need to be able to change the structure of the provider
trees they expose. When moving existing resources, existing allocations
need to be moved along with the inventories. And this must be done in
such a way as to avoid races where a second entity can create or remove
allocations against the moving inventories.

Change-Id: I1508c8e12c75b24ec9da04468b700b60f055ec24
blueprint: reshape-provider-tree

commit_message:
Fix memcached_servers content

The change [1] adapted the memcached_servers content but broke
its templating: its variable content is \\1:{memcached port},
instead of {ip}:{memcached port}.

This should fix the issue.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/d3a0bfb728a75db4c3cc79d4604c8555a472dc6f

Change-Id: I3afdff70a34a101b8cc8d396d41d263d930ee4e2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 15:11:41.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "docs: Disable smartquotes"

This reverts commit 75fc30090133c31316e6ae790568f1b622807d0c. It is no
longer necessary now that oslo.config parses 'Opt.help' as
reStructuredText.

Change-Id: I8f56bdce37cfc538348490052a24e463164c86a3
'}, {'created': '2018-07-11 13:04:22.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "docs: Disable smartquotes"

Bump the minimum version of oslo.config to 6.1.0, which adds proper
support for parsing Opt.help as rST [1]. This in turn allows us to
revert commit 75fc30090133c31316e6ae790568f1b622807d0c, which is a
temporary fix relying on deprecated features of Sphinx.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/553860/

Change-Id: I8f56bdce37cfc538348490052a24e463164c86a3
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "docs: Disable smartquotes"

Bump the minimum version of oslo.config to 6.1.0, which adds proper
support for parsing Opt.help as rST [1]. This in turn allows us to
revert commit 75fc30090133c31316e6ae790568f1b622807d0c, which is a
temporary fix relying on deprecated features of Sphinx.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/553860/

Change-Id: I8f56bdce37cfc538348490052a24e463164c86a3

commit_message:
Invalidate 'computed assignments' cache when creating a project.

Without it, listing projects results were missing project on which the
user had an inherited role.

Change-Id: If8edb3d1d1d3a0dab691ab6c81dd4b42e3b10ab3
Closes-Bug: #1780159

subject: README overview translation to PT_BR
messages:
[{'account_id': 28510, 'date': '2018-06-20 13:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-06-20 13:26:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-07-12 16:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Hi Pedro

Hi James, the idea was to just try my gerrit setup. I'll abandon it"}, {'account_id': 28510, 'date': '2018-07-12 18:23:06.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 28617, 'date': '2018-07-05 14:13:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-06 04:46:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 28617, 'date': '2018-07-08 13:02:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-09 07:46:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Ayyob, please make all the lines shorter than 81 character.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 28617, 'date': '2018-07-09 09:59:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-07-09 10:37:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-10 08:00:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Dougal, may be we should leave all detailed explanations in the docs?

My reasoning is that if we leave too detailed information, like in this case about the language structure, in the code then we increase coupling. That is, if we ever decide to make some changes in the language these comments should also be modified. When operating with such entities in the code I always prefer to keep their descriptions abstract enough, sometimes even following mathematical formalism. I learned from experience that it helps in many cases.

What do you think?

Renat'}, {'account_id': 28617, 'date': '2018-07-10 13:35:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-12 08:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

Please remove trailing spaces and address my comments.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 28617, 'date': '2018-07-12 08:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-12 08:45:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 26431, 'date': '2018-07-12 12:58:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-07-12 15:21:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
taskflow 3.2.0

Releasing this out of the normal Oslo schedule because it uncaps
networkx and we want to have as much time as possible to deal with
any potential issues that may arise as a result of those changes.

Change-Id: I790e5483726842c8a89749c4b9c942f76b2c0b95

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-13 16:38:45.000000000', 'message': 'Increase default connection count to 4096

The current default is 1024 however this is not sufficent for most
deployments and it will cause a lot of issues if it does hit the
limit as the server will stop responding.

The overhead for this is very low and other deployment tooling
usually sets this to 8192[1], so 4096 is even very conservative.

[1]: https://github.com/saz/puppet-memcached/blob/bb9d55a2/manifests/init.pp#L26

Change-Id: I604f96a9431076e1f630d2045eac4c88a92935c1
'}, {'created': '2018-06-13 19:52:26.000000000', 'message': 'Increase default connection count to 4096

The current default is 1024 however this is not sufficent for most
deployments and it will cause a lot of issues if it does hit the
limit as the server will stop responding.

The overhead for this is very low and other deployment tooling
usually sets this to 8192[1], so 4096 is even very conservative.

[1]: https://github.com/saz/puppet-memcached/blob/bb9d55a2/manifests/init.pp#L26

Change-Id: I604f96a9431076e1f630d2045eac4c88a92935c1
'}]
commit_message:
Increase default connection count to 4096

The current default is 1024 however this is not sufficent for most
deployments and it will cause a lot of issues if it does hit the
limit as the server will stop responding.

The overhead for this is very low and other deployment tooling
usually sets this to 8192[1], so 4096 is even very conservative.

[1]: https://github.com/saz/puppet-memcached/blob/bb9d55a2/manifests/init.pp#L26

Change-Id: I604f96a9431076e1f630d2045eac4c88a92935c1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-05 13:47:07.000000000', 'message': 'Enable Python hash seed randomization in tests

Unit tests should run with hash seed randomization
on, to ensure code is not introduced that relies on
ordered access of dicts, sets, etc.

Python 3.3 enables this at runtime by default.

Change-Id: I781fd850039e4817b63edaf275609c1dc47f4949
'}]
commit_message:
Enable Python hash seed randomization in tests

Unit tests should run with hash seed randomization
on, to ensure code is not introduced that relies on
ordered access of dicts, sets, etc.

Python 3.3 enables this at runtime by default.

Change-Id: I781fd850039e4817b63edaf275609c1dc47f4949

Unit tests should run with hash seed randomization
on, to ensure code is not introduced that relies on
ordered access of dicts, sets, etc.

Python 3.3 enables this at runtime by default.

[{'created': '2018-06-19 20:23:55.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for before and after request functions

In flask it is possible to register functions that will run before
and after every request, these are useful for ensuring certain
things occur (setting up environments) and protecting against
cases such as un-enforced API calls not explicitly white-listed.

commit_message:
Add support for before and after request functions

In flask it is possible to register functions that will run before
and after every request, these are useful for ensuring certain
things occur (setting up environments) and protecting against
cases such as un-enforced API calls not explicitly white-listed.

Partial-Bug: #1776504
Change-Id: I0138a4676c1e257cd0c238bbe11a520446c299cb

(11 comments)

To granularize error codes or not?  This is something we need to get right the first time.  I seem to be strongly in favor, Jay seems to be strongly opposed, Chris seems to be somewhere in the middle.

Jay, besides "it's not necessary," do you have other objections?'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-15 10:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

> To granularize error codes or not?  This is something we need to
 > get right the first time.  I seem to be strongly in favor, Jay
 > seems to be strongly opposed, Chris seems to be somewhere in the
 > middle.

My position is effectively "I care if someone besides me is also concerned". Since Eric cares I guess that means I care because that extends my intuitive handwavey concerns to something a bit more concrete.

However, in order to get the granularity of error code that we're describing here, we'd need a somewhat more invasive change: we need to raise a different exception when an RP generation conflict happens, versus a consumer generation. In this patch, we have an operation that does both.

Knowing the difference between those two conflicts is potentially useful for a highly optimized and intelligent client but isn't strictly necessary to get things working.

It is the case that we never want the strings used for error codes to change, but that doesn't mean that a different microversion of a response may not have a different error code, especially if that error code is being used in flow control.

So, if we need a compromise, one option would be to stick with how things are now and pin to this microversion in the resource tracker. Later if we want to have a new microversion which is the same bodies on success, but a different body on a 409, we could create the more granular error codes and enhance the exceptions.

It's a bit early in my coffee pot so I'm not sure how messy this will be but it's an option.

I don't think the world will end whichever option (of the three) we choose.

(haven't actually looked at the code changes in this set, yet, so not leaving any kind of vote)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-15 15:36:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29: Code-Review+2

> So, if we need a compromise

I mostly agree with this.  There's still a low-percentage scenario where this causes pain for the API user, but not really worth worrying about.

Another option is to revert these to the `unspecified` error code and resolve the issue (whichever way we decide) in a subsequent patch.

I'll quit blocking and let Jay and/or other reviewers decide which way we want to go.

The rest of the comments can be resolved in a followon."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-18 16:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29: Code-Review-1

With the merge of the optional placement db stuff, the api_context_manager lines need to be replaced with placement_context_manager or these things are operating in two different database contexts. I think a rebase ought to cause some failures that make it clear.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-19 22:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Patch Set 29 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-19 22:08:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

generations.

commit_message:
Replace port 35357 with 5000 for "auth_url"

Based on the change in Keystone Install Guide [1],
this patch replace port 35357 with 5000 for "auth_url".

For more details, please check similar changes which have been done
on other projects: Nova [2], Neutron [3], Cinder [4], Glance [5].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541857
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562812
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/566491
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565464
[5] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558932

Change-Id: I77b12f0e2bba1adf45f263752647b4ff1dfb40eb

commit_message:
Teach Enforcer.enforce to deal with context objects

The ``creds`` dictionary passed into oslo.policy's enforce() method
assumes a lot of the same values already specified by oslo.context
RequestContext objects.

This commit teaches enforce() to handle being passed an instance of
a RequestContext object, and populate credential values accordingly.

Change-Id: Ia74bf6c40b1e05a1c958f4325e00f68be28d91b9
Closes-Bug: 1779172

commit_message:
Don't assume user's primary group name is the same as username

In certain environments, a user's primary group doesn't necessarily
match that of their username.  This change updates various playbooks to
make use of the `ansible_user_gid` fact instead.

This change also makes ownership explicit by using `ansible_user_uid`
instead of `ansible_user` or `ansible_user_id`, where appropriate.

Change-Id: Ifc2ea7d95ec90e91791ccb10772b15d991379479
Story: 2002770
Task: 22636

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch to stestr as other projects have already moved to it.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: Iddce63084a10cbc5b1670f42acae6c2ee96e0ce8

commit_message:
Support service_domain for reactive charm

Hard coded default domain causes problem sometimes
Adding code for supporting service_domain
Please note that each charm using
layer openstack charm also need to be fixed
if you want to use service_domain instead of default

Change-Id: I1d56359a64c23019151c9c9186ca0c7374735536

commit_message:
enable totp auth plugin

The only config change is in keystone.conf to enable totp auth plugin.

A secret can be generated via an arbitrary tool and uploaded to Keystone
via credential api by specifying "totp" credential type, secret and a
user id.

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/#create-credential

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/totp-auth
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/pike/advanced-topics/auth-totp.html#configuring-totp

Change-Id: Ie3e4d828aae1f0918ace94adbdfdb81ffdc12878

[{'created': '2018-06-19 14:21:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Queens Swift S3 API

Adds new template for Queens that correctly configures
swift3, s3token and proxy pipeline.

Also fixes amulet tests that are currently failing due
to vdb being already mounted in guest and templates
that fail py3.5 due to jinja syntax.

Change-Id: I8ed8a12d2d6adc1f1f3158808101b123ec6bd20d
Closes-Bug: #1775260
(cherry picked from commit fc145319991d738e5ca54ea166c96fe32b025af2)

commit_message:
Fix Queens Swift S3 API

Adds new template for Queens that correctly configures
swift3, s3token and proxy pipeline.

Also fixes amulet tests that are currently failing due
to vdb being already mounted in guest and templates
that fail py3.5 due to jinja syntax.

Change-Id: I8ed8a12d2d6adc1f1f3158808101b123ec6bd20d
Closes-Bug: #1775260
(cherry picked from commit fc145319991d738e5ca54ea166c96fe32b025af2)

messages: [{'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-07-04 07:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-07-04 15:18:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\ncharm-recheck'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-07-12 15:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-04 07:34:52.000000000', 'message': 'Remove uneccessary calls from update_all_identity_relation_units

On every call to update_all_identity_relation_units()
apache was reconfigured and all configuration files written.

This was used for the legacy management of self signed
certificates which now has been removed.

Change-Id: I7480575bc06287f6898ce469b420fd63206015e2
'}]
commit_message:
Remove uneccessary calls from update_all_identity_relation_units

On every call to update_all_identity_relation_units()
apache was reconfigured and all configuration files written.

This was used for the legacy management of self signed
certificates which now has been removed.

Change-Id: I7480575bc06287f6898ce469b420fd63206015e2

commit_message:
Support service_domain domain when enabled v3 api

Adding code for supporting service_domain domain.
When keystone uses v3 api, there are service_domain, admin_domain.
but now default domain is hard coded.

Change-Id: I1206ba7805127f84258efceea5ec9ccb5d8abbdc

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-12 14:05:37.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Convert json_home and version discovery to Flask

Move the JSON Home Document and Version Discovery Documents out of
the webob-based mapper and into Flask.

This change does not remove the mechanisms hooking into the
composing router objects as it aims to make the minimal change set
to ensure parity in functionality.

This change does remove the keystone.version.controller and
keystone.version.router modules as they have been moved into
keystone.api.discovery.

Change-Id: Ib25380cefdbb7147661bb9853de7872a837322e0

Change-Id: Ib25380cefdbb7147661bb9853de7872a837322e0
'}, {'created': '2018-06-12 19:45:44.000000000', 'message': 'Convert json_home and version discovery to Flask

Move the JSON Home Document and Version Discovery Documents out of
the webob-based mapper and into Flask.

This change removes the keystone.version.controller and
keystone.version.router modules as they have been moved into
keystone.api.discovery.

The keystone.api.discovery module is somewhat specialized as there
are no "resources" and it must handle multiple types of responses
based upon the ACCEPTS header (JSON Home or JSON). In lieu of the
flask-RESTful mechanisms, keystone.api.discovery utilizes bare
flask blueprint and functions. Minor scaffolding work has been done
to ensure the discovery blueprint can be loaded via the loader loop
in keystone.server.flask.application (a stub object in
keystone.api.discovery).

Change-Id: Ib25380cefdbb7147661bb9853de7872a837322e0
'}, {'created': '2018-06-12 21:48:25.000000000', 'message': 'Convert json_home and version discovery to Flask

commit_message:
Convert json_home and version discovery to Flask

Move the JSON Home Document and Version Discovery Documents out of
the webob-based mapper and into Flask.

This change removes the keystone.version.controller and
keystone.version.router modules as they have been moved into
keystone.api.discovery.

The keystone.api.discovery module is somewhat specialized as there
are no "resources" and it must handle multiple types of responses
based upon the ACCEPTS header (JSON Home or JSON). In lieu of the
flask-RESTful mechanisms, keystone.api.discovery utilizes bare
flask blueprint and functions. Minor scaffolding work has been done
to ensure the discovery blueprint can be loaded via the loader loop
in keystone.server.flask.application (a stub object in
keystone.api.discovery).

Partial-Bug: #1776504
Change-Id: Ib25380cefdbb7147661bb9853de7872a837322e0

commit_message:
[doc] Use openstack client command to replace neutron client

The neutron client commands will be deprecated, so use
openstack client commands to replace neutron client.

Change-Id: Id7de06bc4c14824dd00206bb5c940c22017ac4d7

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-06-30 00:06:43.000000000', 'message': "Cached tokens in user context and allowed osclient use token for auth

According to some bug report from rally launchpad, when people pe-
rform the task with high concurrency(e.g.100), the Keystone server
becomes very slow and occurs problems.

Let's implement tokens in osclient so that people can choose to
generate and cache tokens in user context object and won't have
to acquire the token again each time when they make a request.

NOTE:
The modification doesn't include any unit test. Please review it
and leave some comments for the implementation or suggestions for
the tests.

Change-Id: Ide0184a9493c28e003b7342dcceff45846ca504c
"}, {'created': '2017-06-30 00:14:23.000000000', 'message': "Cached tokens in user context and allowed osclient use token for auth

According to some bug report from rally launchpad, when people pe-
rform the task with high concurrency(e.g.100), the Keystone server
becomes very slow and occurs problems.

Let's implement tokens in osclient so that people can choose to

NOTE:
The modification doesn't include any unit test. Please review it
and leave some comments for the implementation or suggestions for
the tests.

Change-Id: Ide0184a9493c28e003b7342dcceff45846ca504c
"}, {'created': '2017-06-30 00:35:58.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add ability to use one token per all iterations

Gernating user token is an expensive operations. For the project
that contains multiple iterations, it creates heavy workload to
keystone. I think it would be good if we implement only one token
for all iteratoins to make the keystone process more efficient.

When the 'cache_tokens' is True in the config of users context, one
token will be generated per user and stored in ["users"][*]["token"].
The OpenStackScenario will check if the token is cached and use it
for osclient.

This patch doesn't change default behavior.
The token will only be cached and used when "cache_tokens" is set
to True.

Change-Id: Ide0184a9493c28e003b7342dcceff45846ca504c
Closes-Bug: #1700766

commit_message:
Add ability to use one token per all iterations

Gernating user token is an expensive operations. For the project
that contains multiple iterations, it creates heavy workload to
keystone. I think it would be good if we implement only one token
for all iteratoins to make the keystone process more efficient.

When the 'cache_tokens' is True in the config of users context, one
token will be generated per user and stored in ["users"][*]["token"].
The OpenStackScenario will check if the token is cached and use it
for osclient.

This patch doesn't change default behavior.
The token will only be cached and used when "cache_tokens" is set
to True.

Change-Id: Ide0184a9493c28e003b7342dcceff45846ca504c
Closes-Bug: #1700766

'}, {'created': '2017-03-07 14:05:52.000000000', 'message': 'Allow not writing pxe configs to disk

as part of dynamic iPXE feature implementation, we need a possibility to
not save iPXE configs to disk, as they will be returned from ironic API
instead.

This patch adds a toggle to the methods that render (i)PXE config templates
to optionally not write the template on disk.

Also these methods are now returning the actual config rendered from template
as string.

Change-Id: I65a0d7346f4c35ef8044f4c023a83768c86b2b50
Partial-Bug: #1526275

commit_message:
Allow not writing pxe configs to disk

as part of dynamic iPXE feature implementation, we need a possibility to
not save iPXE configs to disk, as they will be returned from ironic API
instead.

This patch adds a toggle to the methods that render (i)PXE config templates
to optionally not write the template on disk.

Also these methods are now returning the actual config rendered from template
as string.

Change-Id: I65a0d7346f4c35ef8044f4c023a83768c86b2b50
Partial-Bug: #1526275

after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run

commit_message:
Fix sphinx-docs job

build-openstack-sphinx-docs jobs fail on all branches due to the new
pip version 10 introduces some previously Warning as Error: in case of
calling "pip install" without any package name, the command fails.
tox_install.sh is called during docs job without any package passed to pip.

This patch is necessary until the tox_install.sh removal [1] is merged in.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555788

Note: This commit includes the following unrelated changes
to pass the gate.
(Actually I2d125ce2251473f896fc251b8fa51cfa29721850 might not
be necessary on this branch. But I included it as it was a part
of the original commit on master.)
----------------------------------------
Disable failing style checks (W503, E402) for now.

I (yamamoto) guess they are new with pycodestyle 2.4.0.

Related-Bug: #1762795
Change-Id: Ib35d0718bf1410dc8e5c10bb185a00837f2d8b52
----------------------------------------
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: Ib8493a9a2ec30cafa70a67a6f5fd1fee29432ad7
----------------------------------------
Port rally plugins to use proper modules

Sometime ago, all OpenStack related stuff moved from the main repository
to the separate one - https://github.com/openstack/rally-openstack .
All further development and maintance will be done only in a new
repository. As for first major release, the structure is not changed, so
only imports should be changed.

Change-Id: I796e247bcbafc9c5b6d14e30a52e936b16157b8d
(cherry picked from commit 5e82157f3cfcd437e0716356df0cfc06c575e29b)
----------------------------------------
Add dummy docstrings to avoid Sphinx 1.7.x warnings

We need to workaround this locally because:
- It's unclear how long os-vif patch [1] will take
  to be merged.
- While Neutron patch [2] has been merged, docs build on
  gate is using released versions of dependencies.

The idea was taken from keystone. [3]

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/577028/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/577029/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/578121/

Related-Bug: #1771092

commit_message:
Re-add Designate cookbook

In the effort to import the dns and client cookbooks, the dns cookbook
reference was inadvertently left out.

Change-Id: Ibea92346c1d355db0bb71e1533e68168218a7af2

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: I7cd58d35fba69c0f64d5303b48c5bce0816ff36c

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

commit_message:
Handle Munch objects in proxies

First, this patch adds Resource._from_munch.  This method is intended
as temporary means to bridge shade-style Munch objects and original
openstacksdk resources. The base implementation just uses
Resource.__init__ and can be overridden in more complex cases.

Second, Proxy._get_resource was updated to accept Munch objects and
build resources from them. This makes proxy methods transparently
accept Munch objects as long as they contain enough information
to construct the required resource.

Change-Id: I098b0844d420b08fec523789102061dab2ad1e7c

commit_message:
Add ServerDeletionPolicy parameter

With this we could potentially delete or update the heat stack without
deleting any servers, e.g if we wanted to switch from heat/nova managed
server resources to some which are externally managed via Ironic directly.

Partially-Implements: blueprint nova-less-deploy
Change-Id: I2b871c1f096013956904441cddc36cb2404e477a

commit_message:
Add example host confd file for barbican

Missing example file could confuse user to implement this role.
Since the host is not 'barbican' like named.

Change-Id: I00d7801bad50dfbf81720503b38ef1f18ddfe674
(cherry picked from commit 708b51d6d37574d73b1cd4eb666986c9707fa2d1)

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

commit_message:
Move scenario009 to the check queue

This scenario tests OpenShift deployment managed by TripleO on BM
nodes. We got the job working last week and it's been working fine
since then.

Let's move it to the check queue as a non-voting job for now and,
eventually, make it voting.

Change-Id: I3c0a45d04c800678c9e8489218fc3517803b0c23

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-11 21:51:33.000000000', 'message': "Correct severe performance problem

When running our plugins we're seeing a severe performance impact in
the ansible run-time. As it turns out, within the linear strategy we're
looping over all physical hosts in an environment and pulling address
information out to store as a task variable. This action causes all
tasks to reload all {group,host}_vars for all hosts and that repetitive
action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    5m3.236s
  user    6m23.820s
  sys     1m22.344s

Change-Id: I76af71ffe19b2a8afb18ed731f1362a4e399c613
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Correct severe performance problem

When running our plugins we're seeing a severe performance impact in
the ansible run-time. As it turns out, within the linear strategy we're
looping over all physical hosts in an environment and pulling address
information out to store as a task variable. This action causes all
tasks to reload all {group,host}_vars for all hosts and that repetitive
action results in a massive slowdown, especially when there are many
hosts within the inventory.

Results from a normal OSA playbook run on 50 hosts:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    37m44.263s
  user    35m30.984s
  sys     2m23.252s

Results with the strategy plugin disabled on 50 hosts:
  time ANSIBLE_STRATEGY_PLUGINS=false openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml --forks 15
  real    5m8.641s
  user    6m30.792s
  sys     1m32.512s

This change scopes the physical host look up to the task and target host
and adds conditionals around the process to ensure we're not forcing a lookup
that has no chance of succeeding.

Results with this patch applied on 50 hosts and no forks:
  time openstack-ansible openstack-hosts-setup.yml
  real    6m40.573s
  user    7m53.336s
  sys     1m25.828s

Should anything like this come up again debug statements have been added
to the method so that we can enable verbose mode and know what is being
parsed.

Change-Id: I76af71ffe19b2a8afb18ed731f1362a4e399c613
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-22 21:14:47.000000000', 'message': 'Allow custom theme install

Adds a setting custom-theme which operats similar to ubuntu-theme and
default-theme. The provided resource is placed in the themes folder
and apache is setup to serve static content for the theme. This leaves
the default theme untouched allowing the custom theme to override files based
on the built in horizon theme capabilities. For details on theming
capabilities see: https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/configuration/themes.html

Closes-Bug: #1778284

Change-Id: I91ad19e8aad5c0e0773d42fa4f085cbcecb82458

commit_message:
Allow custom theme install

Adds a setting custom-theme which operats similar to ubuntu-theme and
default-theme. The provided resource is placed in the themes folder and
apache is setup to serve static content for the theme. This leaves the
default theme untouched allowing the custom theme to override files
based on the built in horizon theme capabilities. For details on theming
capabilities see:
https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/configuration/themes.html

gnuoy: retry logic for unrelated test updated after a number of CI
failures.

Closes-Bug: #1778284

Change-Id: I91ad19e8aad5c0e0773d42fa4f085cbcecb82458

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-21 03:35:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add policy to InstacenGroup object and api models.

We add the "rules" field to policy object, and the old
InstanceGroup object needs to be adapted to support new
policy object.

The change items in this patch as below:
1. Change "_policies" to "policy" in api_models.InstanceGroup
2. Add a new InstanceGroupPolicy object.
3. Add policy(InstanceGroupPolicy) to InstacenGroup, and adapt
obj method to new object which contains the new policy field.

Related to blueprint complex-anti-affinity-policies

Change-Id: Ib33719a4b9599d86848c618a6e142c71ece79ca5

commit_message:
Add policy to InstanceGroup object

The change items in this patch as below:
1. Add policy and rules to InstanceGroup, deprecate
the policies field.
2. Also, make _from_db_object and _create_in_db method to
support new "policy" field.

The internal usage of InstanceGroup.policies is converted to
use the new model in the REST API and RequestSpec compat code.

Related to blueprint complex-anti-affinity-policies

Change-Id: Ib33719a4b9599d86848c618a6e142c71ece79ca5

commit_message:
Remove testrepository and .testr.conf

This commit is a follow-up of "switch to using stestr"
which was merged already [1].
After switch to using stestr, testrepository and .testr.conf
are unnecessary and should be removed.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/576862

Change-Id: I9f35e4f1341848a62a143b7f7150f2b845575861

commit_message:
add tox env for running requirements-check

Set up a tox environment for running project-requirements-change.py,
the script used in the requirements-check job.

Change-Id: I5336222949acfd947f2ef54ed120e3632b28ccb7
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Update Gemfile for Zuulv3
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 08:00:31.000000000', 'message': 'Update Gemfile for Zuulv3

The logic in the Gemfile was relying on Zuulv2 variables to find out
whether the spec helper gem was already available on disk, and since
Zuulv3 has changed things it was failing to find it and downloading the
master version instead. This patch ensures the Gemfile looks for the gem
in the right place when running in CI.

Change-Id: Id1046d8f6c1a13ab56501c8b2698ab5a1b1051e2
'}]
commit_message:
Update Gemfile for Zuulv3

The logic in the Gemfile was relying on Zuulv2 variables to find out
whether the spec helper gem was already available on disk, and since
Zuulv3 has changed things it was failing to find it and downloading the
master version instead. This patch ensures the Gemfile looks for the gem
in the right place when running in CI.

Change-Id: Id1046d8f6c1a13ab56501c8b2698ab5a1b1051e2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 14:10:44.000000000', 'message': 'Remove dead developer documentation link

This reference was not used anywhere and is causing validation errors
in the release job because it duplicates the implicit anchor that
gets created for the Developer documentation section header.

Change-Id: Ifd6a37948a3adbcfae02ba5316d2ccf5874aece4
'}]
commit_message:
Remove dead developer documentation link

This reference was not used anywhere and is causing validation errors
in the release job because it duplicates the implicit anchor that
gets created for the Developer documentation section header.

Change-Id: Ifd6a37948a3adbcfae02ba5316d2ccf5874aece4

commit_message:
Remove not needed glance variables

As part of cleaning inventory variables, we are
moving some of the variables to be created in
roles instead of the inventory, and removing
variables used only to create other variables and
nowhere else.

Change-Id: I8dfd1904de36ca2b9f163bd5447bfa40ddf4ca3a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-05 14:23:51.000000000', 'message': 'Be consistent with memcached group name

Without this patch, two different groups are used for memcached:
"memcached" and "memcached_all".

This is a problem if you want to deploy openstack-ansible with a
static inventory, and only define one of the groups "memcached".
You would define the group "memcached" because it is already the
one used in the group_vars, and it makes more sense as there is
only a single component in "memcached" (unlike nova, cinder, ...).

This patches solves the problem by ensuring the only group used
for memcached is named "memcached" and not "memcached_all".

Change-Id: Ie7ff9a33df8d0eabdee8307a4f8ef5694c72bdd9
'}]
commit_message:
Be consistent with memcached group name

Without this patch, two different groups are used for memcached:
"memcached" and "memcached_all".

This is a problem if you want to deploy openstack-ansible with a
static inventory, and only define one of the groups "memcached".
You would define the group "memcached" because it is already the
one used in the group_vars, and it makes more sense as there is
only a single component in "memcached" (unlike nova, cinder, ...).

This patches solves the problem by ensuring the only group used
for memcached is named "memcached" and not "memcached_all".

Change-Id: Ie7ff9a33df8d0eabdee8307a4f8ef5694c72bdd9

commit_message:
fix series name handling in new-release

The independent series has to be treated as a special case because it
does not appear in the sequence of normal series.

Not everything in the deliverables directory is actually a series
name, so we need to use the series status data to get the list of
valid names.

Change-Id: Iea9ce55bf3c99afc7bcdd74cc0b7eb523c0a922d
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-10 18:25:43.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: use fqdn for zuul projects

When setting up a 3pci zuul, there is an edge case where a downstream
zuul may already have openstack/foo projects, eg:
review.rdoproject.org/openstack/foo.  In this case, if openstack
projects are not namespaced to include the connection information zuul
gets confused and complains.  We can avoid this by using the fqdn for
git.o.o for devstack jobs and both upstream and downstream zuul will
properly use the correct connection.

Change-Id: I01419ea9f51ce7491aa319b6240aec9c0d4f2356
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-07-10 22:36:32.000000000', 'message': 'use fqdn for zuul projects

When setting up a 3pci zuul, there is an edge case where a downstream

projects are not namespaced to include the connection information zuul
gets confused and complains.  We can avoid this by using the fqdn for
git.o.o for devstack jobs and both upstream and downstream zuul will
properly use the correct connection.

Change-Id: I01419ea9f51ce7491aa319b6240aec9c0d4f2356
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
use fqdn for zuul projects

When setting up a 3pci zuul, there is an edge case where a downstream
zuul may already have openstack/foo projects, eg:
review.rdoproject.org/openstack/foo.  In this case, if openstack
projects are not namespaced to include the connection information zuul
gets confused and complains.  We can avoid this by using the fqdn for
git.o.o for devstack jobs and both upstream and downstream zuul will
properly use the correct connection.

Change-Id: I01419ea9f51ce7491aa319b6240aec9c0d4f2356
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Drop use of identity admin endpoint

The admin identity endpoint has been removed, so we can no longer create
resources using it. Use the public identity endpoint instead.

Change-Id: I002beefb44e755a8e3ba1965644246d02f328d7b

Question:
---------
We have 3 project drivers (pod, service, namespace) and for all of them we support only the default one (project = neutron_default.project)

Do we expect/plan to support other project drivers?
Does it means that it might be that pods, services, namespace will belong to different projects? or it just driver implementation for other SDNs (e.g: Dragonflow)?

Will Kuryr's current implementation work if will have separate projects for pod,service,namespace?"}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2018-07-11 10:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2018-07-11 10:53:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@yossi: For now they belong to the same, but there may be some driver extensions to provide different implementations of some of them, for instance each pod (neutron port) being on a different project id. 

And regarding if kuryr will work with that... well, until this got merged https://review.openstack.org/#/c/580297/ the subnet resources were not using the same project as the pod ones (neutron ports). So, for some resources it may work, for others it may not'}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-07-12 04:48:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14885, 'date': '2018-07-12 12:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add default namespace project driver

This patch adds a new default driver to get the project ID
associated to a namespace. Same as the pod and service project
drivers

Partially Implements: blueprint network-namespace

Change-Id: Ib4306ba2c3d07ddfa311e2970b67d8b617c951e7

commit_message:
Support same projects in different domain

Getting 500 error when there are same project name
in different domain.
Selecting one domain from service_credentials.
e.g. services(or service) projects are in default and service_domain
having differrent id. so this selects default's services project
instead of service_domain's services project

This is backported from e923493e4feec239c9fe9b58736960a40e373bee

Change-Id: I3f12811684a49794bca87c4a10b18d45879da773
Closes-Bug: #1776375

"}, {'created': '2018-07-12 08:16:51.000000000', 'message': "Retry nova-status check and only run it once

Also, sometimes the API is not yet ready, so we implement some

it.

Finally, the task is renamed to make it more descriptive to those

Change-Id: Iea8a71653df5a8506b0e29f587585d9dfb5a7a1b
"}]
commit_message:
Retry nova-status check and only run it once

In https://review.openstack.org/575125 the nova-statuc check was
implemented to run on the control plane nodes to verify a healthy
environment.

Instead of running on all control plane nodes, we set it to only
run on the first one to ensure that the play stops if it fails
which will hopefully leave a running environment, giving time for
deployers to fix it.

Also, sometimes the API is not yet ready, so we implement some
retries to ensure that extra time is given for any API's that need
it.

Finally, the task is renamed to make it more descriptive to those
who are unfamiliar with what nova-status is and its purpose.

Change-Id: Iea8a71653df5a8506b0e29f587585d9dfb5a7a1b

commit_message:
ODL to log to file for containerised deployments

ODL was configured to log to console and then access
logs via docker logs. journal deletes older logs and
sometimes the old logs are not available. Move back
to logging to file, which is a default mechanism.
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/
blob/stable/queens/puppet/services/opendaylight-api.yaml#L68

All relevant changes are already merged.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567469/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565756/

There is WIP patch to move to stand-alone log config
file for Rocky.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575416/

Change-Id: I686af4a85a3728b4583f376d28bdb1151845b25d
Closes-Bug: 1779627

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-30 16:57:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up pm_addr when undercloud_local_ip is specified

In tripleo-quickstart/roles/libvirt/setup/overcloud/templates/instackenv.json.j2
we have the following:

 "pm_addr": "{{ undercloud_local_ip|default(undercloud_network_cidr|nthhost(1)) }}",

If you specify an undercloud_local_ip parameter without the netmask the
undercloud installation will fail because it actually does require a
netmask to be added. See:
https://github.com/openstack/instack-undercloud/blob/master/instack_undercloud/undercloud.py#L142
https://github.com/openstack/instack-undercloud/blob/master/instack_undercloud/undercloud.py#L1421

So if you specify an ip with netmask (say 192.168.24.1) the instackenv.json file will be broken:

"name": "control-2",
"pm_password": "foo",
"pm_type": "ipmi",
"pm_user": "admin",
"pm_addr": "192.168.24.1/24",
"pm_port": "6232",
"mac": [ "00:b0:d5:84:0f:11" ],

ipmitool will fail the call to 192.168.24.1/24 (as it does not like the added netmask)
and hence ironic node registration will fail.

Let's just pick the first host for both undercloud_network_cidr and
undercloud_local_ip, no matter what.

Change-Id: I55afef6f7133b87c45b4dec41095c1fba65f3703
Closes-Bug: #1774232
'}, {'created': '2018-07-10 15:38:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up pm_addr when undercloud_local_ip is specified

commit_message:
Fix up pm_addr when undercloud_local_ip is specified

In tripleo-quickstart/roles/libvirt/setup/overcloud/templates/instackenv.json.j2
we have the following:

 "pm_addr": "{{ undercloud_local_ip|default(undercloud_network_cidr|nthhost(1)) }}",

If you specify an undercloud_local_ip parameter without the netmask the
undercloud installation will fail because it actually does require a
netmask to be added. See:
https://github.com/openstack/instack-undercloud/blob/master/instack_undercloud/undercloud.py#L142
https://github.com/openstack/instack-undercloud/blob/master/instack_undercloud/undercloud.py#L1421

So if you specify an ip with netmask (say 192.168.24.1) the instackenv.json file will be broken:

"name": "control-2",
"pm_password": "foo",
"pm_type": "ipmi",
"pm_user": "admin",
"pm_addr": "192.168.24.1/24",
"pm_port": "6232",
"mac": [ "00:b0:d5:84:0f:11" ],

ipmitool will fail the call to 192.168.24.1/24 (as it does not like the added netmask)
and hence ironic node registration will fail.

Let's just pick the first host for both undercloud_network_cidr and
undercloud_local_ip, no matter what.

Change-Id: I55afef6f7133b87c45b4dec41095c1fba65f3703
Closes-Bug: #1774232

commit_message:
Increase max heat stack depth

We've previously increased this to 7 in instack-undercloud because of
containers. As we switch to containerized undercloud we need to continue
to incrase this to 7.

See Ib31bf29bc69f5c58e98b99c3e598b19c99efc77f for history.

Change-Id: Id9facbc53ac5166fcc544157bf820389fa00efac
Related-Blueprint: containerized-undercloud

A good chunk of container images try to be as slim as possible and as
a consequence do not have repoquery binary which is used to limit the
packages to a given repo. Luckily yum provides out of the box the same
feature via a '--repo' option that allows to enable just that repo.

Change-Id: I81e5cd0edae56c1535a2e4dcc639ec71055b10d2
"}, {'created': '2018-06-21 10:19:40.000000000', 'message': 'Remove dependency on repoquery

Change-Id: I81e5cd0edae56c1535a2e4dcc639ec71055b10d2
'}, {'created': '2018-06-21 12:26:17.000000000', 'message': "Do not fail when repoquery is not installed

A good chunk of container images try to be as slim as possible and as
a consequence do not have repoquery binary which is used to limit the
packages to a given repo.

This commit makes the playbook more against these containers and
installs all available updates when repoquery is not installed, the
same as when we don't restrict the list of repositories to get updates
from.

Change-Id: I81e5cd0edae56c1535a2e4dcc639ec71055b10d2
"}]
commit_message:
Do not fail when repoquery is not installed

A good chunk of container images try to be as slim as possible and as
a consequence do not have repoquery binary which is used to limit the
packages to a given repo.

This commit makes the playbook more against these containers and
installs all available updates when repoquery is not installed, the
same as when we don't restrict the list of repositories to get updates
from.

Change-Id: I81e5cd0edae56c1535a2e4dcc639ec71055b10d2

commit_message:
Reconcile all 'Ansible control host' references

Ensure all references to the Ansible control host are worded as such, to
ensure consistency and avoid potential confusion with the OpenStack
controllers.

Change-Id: Id92e537ccbfdd55287b8eae296f649640c70ce17

Nice work, Jorge,  I do have one question, however.  I recall that one of the potential issues when I looked into the alertmanager functionality was that unless the alertmanagers were properly clustered, multiple alertmanager instances could send duplicate alerts for the same event (each instance de-dups, but each may send the same alert once).  I'm not an expert in this area, however, so I'm really not familiar with what is required to prevent that.  Does your setup prevent this?  Other than that one potential issue (which may not even be a problem) this looks good to me."}, {'account_id': 2276, 'date': '2018-06-11 15:03:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2276, 'date': '2018-06-11 16:29:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Nice work, Jorge,  I do have one question, however.  I recall that
 > one of the potential issues when I looked into the alertmanager
 > functionality was that unless the alertmanagers were properly
 > clustered, multiple alertmanager instances could send duplicate
 > alerts for the same event (each instance de-dups, but each may send
 > the same alert once).  I'm not an expert in this area, however, so
 > I'm really not familiar with what is required to prevent that. 
 > Does your setup prevent this?  Other than that one potential issue
 > (which may not even be a problem) this looks good to me.

Mark, I haven't seen any duplicate alert by using the mesh configuration (cluster), but that doesn't means that duplicate alerts can always happen (if the mesh fails, etc). At the moment
after a few weeks using it, I haven't seen any duplicate, so I think we are on a safe page in that regards."}, {'account_id': 24147, 'date': '2018-06-11 19:09:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-01 21:05:52.000000000', 'message': '[prometheus] Initial implementation of prometheus-alertmanager

This patch extends the prometheus role for being able
to deploy the prometheus-alertmanager[0] container.

The variable enable_prometheus_alertmanager
decides if the container should be deployed and enabled.

If enabled, the following configuration and actions are performed:

- The alerting section on the prometheus-server configuration
is added pointing the prometheus-alertmanager host group as targets.

- HAProxy is configured to load-balance over the prometheus-alertmanager
host group. (external/internal).

Please note that a default (dummy) configuration is provided, that
allows the service to start, the operator should extend it via a node custom config

[0] https://github.com/openstack/kolla/tree/master/docker/prometheus/prometheus-alertmanager

Change-Id: I3a13342c67744a278cc8d52900a913c3ccc452ae
Closes-Bug: 1774725
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@linaro.org>
'}, {'created': '2018-06-01 21:07:19.000000000', 'message': '[prometheus] Initial implementation of prometheus-alertmanager

decides if the container should be deployed and enabled.

If enabled, the following configuration and actions are performed:

- The alerting section on the prometheus-server configuration
is added pointing the prometheus-alertmanager host group as targets.

- HAProxy is configured to load-balance over the prometheus-alertmanager
host group. (external/internal).

Please note that a default (dummy) configuration is provided, that
allows the service to start, the operator should extend it via a node custom config

[0] https://github.com/openstack/kolla/tree/master/docker/prometheus/prometheus-alertmanager

Change-Id: I3a13342c67744a278cc8d52900a913c3ccc452ae
Closes-Bug: 1774725

commit_message:
[prometheus] Initial implementation of prometheus-alertmanager

This patch extends the prometheus role for being able
to deploy the prometheus-alertmanager[0] container.

The variable enable_prometheus_alertmanager
decides if the container should be deployed and enabled.

If enabled, the following configuration and actions are performed:

- The alerting section on the prometheus-server configuration
is added pointing the prometheus-alertmanager host group as targets.

- HAProxy is configured to load-balance over the prometheus-alertmanager
host group. (external/internal).

Please note that a default (dummy) configuration is provided, that
allows the service to start, the operator should extend it via a node custom config

[0] https://github.com/openstack/kolla/tree/master/docker/prometheus/prometheus-alertmanager

Change-Id: I3a13342c67744a278cc8d52900a913c3ccc452ae
Closes-Bug: 1774725
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@linaro.org>

commit_message:
Running tests in serial

Adding the following job which runs tempest tests in serial:
kuryr-kubernetes-tempest-daemon-containerized-openshift-octavia-serial

This is needed, for example, to a test like "Test restart of CNI and
Controller kuryr pods" which can cause problems when running in parallel with
other tests.

Also configured kuryr-kubernetes-tempest-daemon-pools-octavia to run the
tests in serial

Change-Id: Ie961a0ceeb33a6da285afba0019551ce5b54f905

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-19 08:20:08.000000000', 'message': 'Accurate L3 IP tc filter limit

Currently the L3 agent qos extension does not set the mtu for
tc filter rules, the default default is 2k. Tc filter ruls use
such mtu will result an inaccurate bandwidth.

So in order to improve the precision, we set the mtu to 64kb.
For the test results, you can read the bug description.

For more information you can read the linux tc man page:
[1] https://linux.die.net/man/8/tc-tbf
[2] http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/tc-police.8.html

Closes-Bug: #1777598
Change-Id: I7a167ec6139ccc55988b34f82080a182116d02a3
'}, {'created': '2018-06-20 02:21:37.000000000', 'message': 'Make L3 IP tc filter rate limit more accurate

Currently the L3 agent qos extension does not set the mtu for
tc filter rules, the default value is 2kb. Tc filter rules use
such mtu will result in an inaccurate bandwidth.

So in order to improve the precision, we set the mtu to 64kb.
For the test results, you can read the bug description.

For more information you can read the linux tc man page:
[1] https://linux.die.net/man/8/tc-tbf
[2] http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/tc-police.8.html

Closes-Bug: #1777598
Change-Id: I7a167ec6139ccc55988b34f82080a182116d02a3
'}]
commit_message:
Make L3 IP tc filter rate limit more accurate

Currently the L3 agent qos extension does not set the mtu for
tc filter rules, the default value is 2kb. Tc filter rules use
such mtu will result in an inaccurate bandwidth.

So in order to improve the precision, we set the mtu to 64kb.
For the test results, you can read the bug description.

For more information you can read the linux tc man page:
[1] https://linux.die.net/man/8/tc-tbf
[2] http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/tc-police.8.html

Closes-Bug: #1777598
Change-Id: I7a167ec6139ccc55988b34f82080a182116d02a3

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

instead of "networking_bgpvpn".

commit_message:
Use get_marker_obj from neutron-lib

With version 0.14.0, _get_marker_obj from neutron.db._utils
was rehomed into neutron-lib.  Consume it.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: If178cb5a15973d5bf3645636647c636a50b300f9

subject: PUT+POST: simplify object server POST handler, other fixes
messages:
[{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-14 17:49:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-06-14 20:30:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I think I like this, but I do not understand why it's valid to update object server after the commit to durable, but not before. The object exists, bytes count against quota, even for non-durable objects... or not?"}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-15 10:42:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm reloading the context myself, but I think the reasoning is that non-durable fragments will eventually be reclaimed [1] so we wouldn't want a container db entry for them.

However, further thoughts: for an encrypted replicated policy PUT that needs to send metadata after the initial PUT, the commit is  no-op and we actually only need a PUT+POST (not PUT+POST+POST). Ideally we'd be able to avoid the second POST in that case and have the update triggered by the first (and only) POST. So something a little different to this patch is probably needed ultimately.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/46ee580e707c3b8bcdcd5de49391f025a2016433/swift/obj/diskfile.py#L3533-L3537"}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-15 12:13:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-19 14:55:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-19 14:58:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Squash if agreeable.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-06-21 04:29:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-06-26 14:47:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Squashed into https://review.openstack.org/427911
Alistair, you might want to ensure I didn't drop something important and then abandon."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-07-12 09:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

squashed into https://review.openstack.org/427911'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-14 17:49:39.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: PUT POST: simplify object server POST handler

Change-Id: Ic1204a51eb0574c68547d78fc69d0ba54f040b2c
'}, {'created': '2018-06-15 12:13:53.000000000', 'message': "WIP: PUT POST: simplify object server POST handler

Try to support PUT+single POST for replication policy and
PUT+POST+POST for EC policies.

I haven't completed plumbing through the replication policy case,
just added a X-Backend-Finalize header and refactored the server
side to handle both the metadata write and call to commit in one
POST handler.

Definitely WIP. I can upload an object to EC policy with this.

Change-Id: Ic1204a51eb0574c68547d78fc69d0ba54f040b2c
"}, {'created': '2018-06-19 14:55:58.000000000', 'message': 'PUT+POST: simplify object server POST handler, other fixes

Make the DoublePutter the default choice so that func tests
use it. Thi smay change before landing on master but seems like
a good idea while the patch is in development.

Support PUT+single POST for replication policy and
PUT+POST+POST for EC policies.

Ensure that container udpate routing headers are available with
the POST that triggers the container update.

Change-Id: Ic1204a51eb0574c68547d78fc69d0ba54f040b2c
'}]
commit_message:
PUT+POST: simplify object server POST handler, other fixes

Make the DoublePutter the default choice so that func tests
use it. Thi smay change before landing on master but seems like
a good idea while the patch is in development.

Support PUT+single POST for replication policy and
PUT+POST+POST for EC policies.

Ensure that container udpate routing headers are available with
the POST that triggers the container update.

Change-Id: Ic1204a51eb0574c68547d78fc69d0ba54f040b2c

commit_message:
Add --architecture support when uploading images

Adding --architecture when uploading images will set a hw_architecture image
meta data property and prefix all images with the arch to make them
stand out in an openstack image list

While tripleo doesn't yet take advantage of using the image meta data
it's still helpful for manual testing to ensure that image selection
implies appropriate hardware.

Support is added in such a way that that image names are not altered if
no --architecture is specified.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Change-Id: I352759014ce4c249d8391b03317012000221f96f

(12 comments)

Logically, this patch looks to be in good shape. 

I do have a couple of recurring issues in the patch as written:
1) There is extensive use on private variables outside the class that should be fixed with setter and accessor methods. 

2) The same variable is used for lists and dicts interchangeably and often in the same line of code. This is extremely confusing and will likely lead to maintenance issues. A new variable for the list in these cases would help a lot. 

There are a couple of minor issues too while fixing the above. subject: Use prefix length for CIDR in DeployedServerPortMap
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-10 17:53:11.000000000', 'message': "Use prefix length for CIDR in DeployedServerPortMap

The cidr key takes the prefix length in DeployedServerPortMap, not the
full CIDR notation. For example, for 192.168.24.1/24, the value should
be 24.

We have to use 'cidr' as the key, even though it is a bit of a misnmoer
because the structure accepted by DeployedServerPortMap has to match
the structure of OS::Neutron::Port resources in Heat.

Change-Id: I05ed17e2a24f9744466adedd86aa4b8852c51fc9
"}]
commit_message:
Use prefix length for CIDR in DeployedServerPortMap

The cidr key takes the prefix length in DeployedServerPortMap, not the
full CIDR notation. For example, for 192.168.24.1/24, the value should
be 24.

We have to use 'cidr' as the key, even though it is a bit of a misnmoer
because the structure accepted by DeployedServerPortMap has to match
the structure of OS::Neutron::Port resources in Heat.

Change-Id: I05ed17e2a24f9744466adedd86aa4b8852c51fc9

[{'created': '2018-07-09 18:54:51.000000000', 'message': "Add (back) --keep-running

Adds back the --keep-running cli arg that can be used to skip the kill
heat steps. This is useful for debugging stack failures and stack
behavior in the ephemeral Heat.

The help text includes how to interact with the ephemeral Heat since
it's non-obvious.

Change-Id: Idb0c05b7b1ccd10b93f0b10bbabcc4beadcc7dbb
"}]
commit_message:
Add (back) --keep-running

Adds back the --keep-running cli arg that can be used to skip the kill
heat steps. This is useful for debugging stack failures and stack
behavior in the ephemeral Heat.

The help text includes how to interact with the ephemeral Heat since
it's non-obvious.

Change-Id: Idb0c05b7b1ccd10b93f0b10bbabcc4beadcc7dbb

commit_message:
Handle 408 and 503 error by trying once more.

If 408(timeout), 503(service unavailable) errors
encountered then handle the error by requesting
one more time.

Change-Id: I6b014265d149c01c7df9cbe7c9fc112739726add
Closes-Bug: #1535750

[{'created': '2018-07-09 18:48:32.000000000', 'message': 'Default --local-domain to localdomain

tripleo deploy is no longer undercloud specific, so a better default for
--local-domain is localdomain instead of undercloud. And in fact, the
undercloud installer already defaults to localdomain in
tripleoclient/config/undercloud.py

Change-Id: I9f20e546b39ffb604b21e57e8bfa3a1e1fd7dde2
'}]
commit_message:
Default --local-domain to localdomain

tripleo deploy is no longer undercloud specific, so a better default for
--local-domain is localdomain instead of undercloud. And in fact, the
undercloud installer already defaults to localdomain in
tripleoclient/config/undercloud.py

Change-Id: I9f20e546b39ffb604b21e57e8bfa3a1e1fd7dde2

commit_message:
Updating required neutron version

build-openstack-sphinx-docs gate was raising an error and -1 on the
gate, due to neutron out of date version (12.0.0). This patch will bring
neutron from 13.0.0.0b2 to the newest version.

Error logs:
   ubuntu-xenial |     'router': constants.L3,
   ubuntu-xenial | AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'L3'

Please see more error logs in the following link
http://logs.openstack.org/04/557904/8/check/build-openstack-sphinx-docs/7a6b1da/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-07-03_04_00_47_083795

Change-Id: I938d1a597c6cbdf6a1f6d2de4f0944b610a4a7d6

commit_message:
Setting values for OS_* from environment var in defaults/main.yml

In order to enable other clouds to be used with ovb-manage-stack role
like personal tennants, instead of have to parse the values as -e
arguments, it might be a good idea to have it from environment
variables sourced from the rc file generated by openstack.

Change-Id: I45385c85a97eee6eba3788ca5aabf1e7e20da32c

[{'created': '2018-07-05 10:16:14.000000000', 'message': "Adds support for the cpu_model customisation in nova.conf

When the cpu_mode is set to 'custom' then the cpu_model configuration
item must also be supplied. This change simply allows this to be customised
via a user variable. In our case, we use this setting to set a lowest common
denominator CPU model in order to perform live migrations between
hypervisors with slightly different CPU architectures.

Change-Id: I87b22214dccc9cfa64ffc576812e735b98b9dac4
"}]
commit_message:
Adds support for the cpu_model customisation in nova.conf

When the cpu_mode is set to 'custom' then the cpu_model configuration
item must also be supplied. This change simply allows this to be customised
via a user variable. In our case, we use this setting to set a lowest common
denominator CPU model in order to perform live migrations between
hypervisors with slightly different CPU architectures.

Change-Id: I87b22214dccc9cfa64ffc576812e735b98b9dac4

plz see above original one'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 08:10:35.000000000', 'message': 'Recognize the devices that failed to get ts as removed

Current device change detection logic have 2 separate function calls to
get device information(get_all_devices, get_devices_modified_timestamps)
but these operation are not treated as a atomic operation.
Some devices that exists when get_all_devices evaluated can disappear
when get_devices_modified_timestamps evaluated.
This inconsitency need to feedback to the result of get_all_devices
which is executed first. Otherwise this can cause problem to
miss updated devices(bug/1781129)

Change-Id: I0ed97653745d1d0bfeaace3c32325fa31cc66580
Closes-Bug: #1781129
'}]
commit_message:
Recognize the devices that failed to get ts as removed

Current device change detection logic have 2 separate function calls to
get device information(get_all_devices, get_devices_modified_timestamps)
but these operation are not treated as a atomic operation.
Some devices that exists when get_all_devices evaluated can disappear
when get_devices_modified_timestamps evaluated.
This inconsitency need to feedback to the result of get_all_devices
which is executed first. Otherwise this can cause problem to
miss updated devices(bug/1781129)

Change-Id: I0ed97653745d1d0bfeaace3c32325fa31cc66580
Closes-Bug: #1781129
